ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

REVIEW ON USE OF CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND
(For purchase of trustee stocks)


    The following question stood in the name of Mr S. Chandra Das:-

    1. To ask the Minister for Labour whether he will review the use of Central Provident Fund for the purchase of trustee stocks.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (Mountbatten): Question No. 1, Sir.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the CPF Investment Scheme was first introduced in 1986, CPF members were generally unfamiliar with investments in the stock market. Government decided to restrict CPF investments in shares to companies which meet the criteria in the Trustees Act. The intention was to exclude non-trustee companies which are smaller and without a track record. When the Investment

Column: 483

Scheme was liberalised in 1993, non-trustee shares were allowed subject to some limits under the Basic Investment Scheme. As for the Enhanced Investment Scheme, no restrictions were placed on non-trustee shares.

    Companies which meet the trustee criteria have generally been stable. However, this cannot be taken to mean that investment in trustee stocks is guaranteed to be safe and sound. That is why CPF members are urged to exercise prudence and judgment in investing their CPF savings. By requiring CPF members to set aside their Minimum Sum and limiting them to investing 80% of the remaining balance, the CPF Board has helped to reduce members' exposure to risks in the stock market.

    In January 1997, the CPF Board will merge the Basic and Enhanced Investment Schemes into a single CPF Investment Scheme. Under this Scheme, eligible members will be able to invest up to a maximum of 20% of their available savings in non-trustee stocks. This was announced on 19th March 1996 when I informed this House of the merging of the Investment Schemes.

Column: 483

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND BOARD
(Recovery of CPF moneys from people affected by
compulsory acquisition of land)


    2. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for Labour whether, in view of the financial need to initiate the relocation process, the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board will refrain from recovering CPF moneys from the 20% advance compensation payment of those affected by the compulsory acquisition of land for the North-East MRT line and comprehensive development and to do so only after they have received the remaining compensation.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, CPF savings are meant for a member's retirement needs. That is why all moneys withdrawn under the CPF housing schemes must be returned to the member's CPF account, together with any accrued interest, when the property is sold

Column: 484

or transferred. The rationale is no different for properties acquired under the Land Acquisition Act.

    When the advance payment of compensation package was introduced, Government made a conscious decision not to interfere in the financing arrangements that affected land owners may have made for the acquired properties. This position is applied equally to all parties which have claims on the compensation awards, including the CPF Board and the lending banks.

    Those who face a cash flow problem already have a way out, which is to surrender the title and undertake to deliver vacant possession before they are paid the full 100% compensation award, part of which they can use as payment for an alternative property.

    Let me add that Land Office will expedite the processing and payment of the awards. Priority will be given to individual owners with genuine cash flow problems. If the land owners wish to, they can occupy the same property on rental until it is required by the authorities for development.

    In view of the above, my Ministry is unable to accede to the Member's request for CPF Board to refrain from restoring CPF moneys from the 20% advance compensation payment to CPF members.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Thomson GRC): Sir, in view of the fact that the CPF Board is a statutory board, unlike the commercial banks, and also the owners are being asked to move out because of the compulsory acquisition, and they need the money to assist them in the relocation and pay the initial payments for their next home, will the Minister re-consider his decision?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact, we have considered all these factors that the Member has brought up and, as I said in my main answer, the solution to members who are affected by cash flow problems is to now opt to surrender the property to the Land Office and to collect the 100% compensation award which, as I said earlier on, the Land Office will

Column: 485

expedite the processing of such claims and the affected land owner or property owner can get the full payment quickly and he can proceed to make arrangements for alternative premises, whether it is a shop or a home. But in so far as the CPF money that has been used for the purchase of this property is concerned, the present rule must apply because, as I said, not only will such owners face similar claims by the lending banks, they also have to ensure that they are able to meet their obligations to the banks that have loaned them the money. Even if the CPF Board does not want to make a claim, the banks may well proceed to make the same claim. So there is no assurance that this method will solve the problems of the affected property owner. The best solution is to opt to surrender the property, collect the full compensation and then make arrangement to buy an alternative property. In the interim, he can continue to occupy the premises and pay a small rental to the Land Office.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Will the Minister review the situation in view of the fact that we are here discussing moneys which are rightfully that of the home owners and it is with a statutory board, not a commercial bank, and also that the home owners will return the money to the CPF after they have received the total compensation? All they need is the initial money to pay for the downpayment for their next home. And in view of the fact that they are being moved out because of compulsory acquisition by the Government, will the Minister show some compassion for them?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, of course, I am very sympathetic to those property owners whose properties have been acquired. The question of why these properties have been acquired had been discussed at length on other occasions. I think right now we are talking about whether the 20% upfront compensation should be left entirely to the discretion of the property owner or should be utilised as he had already committed himself to, ie, when he took money from the CPF account to purchase this property, he had

Column: 486

allowed a charge to be placed on the property. Whether the property is subsequently sold, transferred or acquired by Government makes no difference. He should refund the money that he has first received in payment for the property to the agency which has a charge on the property. We have to maintain this principle. Otherwise, we could allow ourselves to be caught in all kinds of situations. In future, there will be other claims and requests and the protection of the CPF savings will not be complete. Our concern right now is to ensure that the members' CPF savings are properly protected.

    I agree that he is in a difficult position because his property has been acquired, but the solution to his problem cannot be to waive the protection that is necessary for his CPF savings. The solution for him is, as I said earlier on, to take the 100% compensation that is available to him immediately. It would be made available as soon as his case is reviewed by the Land Office. The Land Office has assured me that they would expedite all such cases to ensure that compensation awards are paid expeditiously. I think that is the only solution.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Sir, in view of the fact that the home owners need time to purchase their next home and the fact that they will return the charge, which is rightfully the CPF, at a later date after they have received full compensation, will the Minister use his discretion, and I understand that he has the discretionary power, to intervene to prevent the CPF from immediately imposing the charge?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, I have tried to explain to the Member that even if the CPF Board were not to proceed with the charge to seek the reinstatement of the CPF savings that have been withdrawn, it does not mean that the member can enjoy the full 20%. It may well be that he has to meet his obligation under his mortgage. The banks may also want to make their claim. So the solution as advocated by the Member is incomplete because although the CPF Board may be prepared to waive the charge, private lending banks may not want to waive the charge. So the member will still have the

Column: 487

same problem. The real solution for the member who has a cash flow problem now in trying to find alternative premises is to take up the offer of the Land Office: take full compensation, remain on the property for as long as he needs to during the transitional stage and then move out when his new property is ready or when it is required for development.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Sir, I agree with the Minister that if it is a charge by a commercial bank, the home owners will have no choice. But in view of the fact that this charge is by the CPF Board, which is a statutory board, and it is a matter of time that they will eventually return the moneys to the CPF Board, will the Minister reconsider his decision? Because many of them are in financial difficulties and they need the money to put the downpayment for their next home and they are moving out in view of Government acquisition, not of their own choice.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, some property owners have also taken up bank loans apart from withdrawing money from their CPF accounts to finance the purchase of their properties. Therefore, it is not only a case of settling the issue with the CPF Board. There are other lending institutions involved too which have also placed equal charges on these properties.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister is not answering my question. My question is: if the charge is by the CPF Board, not a commercial bank, will the CPF give this concession?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is no.

Column: 487

COMPULSORY ACQUISITION OF LAND FOR NORTH-EAST MRT LINE
(Alternative accommodation for affected residents)


    3. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for Law whether he will allow the residents who have given up their homes as a result of the compulsory acquisition of land for the North-East MRT line and comprehensive development to stay on in the acquired homes at a nominal rental

Column: 488

until they are able to relocate to their new homes, and, if not, whether he will consider providing alternative accommodation at a nominal rate to the residents affected.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Law): Mr Speaker, Sir, the question of rental only arises if the landowner has received his full compensation moneys but wants to remain on the acquired land. He has, in fact, the alternative of receiving only 20% of the compensation moneys and staying on rent-free on the acquired land until it is due for possession by the Land Office.

    Once a landowner surrenders his acquired land in return for full compensation, he should vacate the site. Allowing him to remain on the land at nominal rental after the acquisition would defeat the purpose of paying him full compensation at vacant possession rate. The Government already makes a concession by allowing him to remain on State land by paying a rental as assessed by the Chief Valuer.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Sir, in view of what the Minister for Labour has just said that he would not relent to the owners' request that the 20% advance compensation be waived from the CPF charge and that there would also be a charge by commercial banks, some owners will have tremendous difficulty in moving to their next home. And in view of the fact that some of them have to move by March of 1997, they need time. They need the money to buy the next home and need time to move. And some of them need time to renovate. In view of all these, after they have received the full compensation, will the Minister concerned take this into consideration and allow them to continue to stay in their previous homes at nominal rental?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, Government realises that this is indeed a massive infrastructural project. Completion is estimated at seven years. And, in fact, for the land acquisition exercise, we have phased it out over five years - three scheduled dates for taking

Column: 489

possession - and all landowners already know at this point in time when they are supposed to move out. In other words, there is advance notice and they can plan accordingly. So they have a choice. If they do not want to move out and they want to stay, they will get the 20%. Very soon we are processing that, and we are going to pay that very shortly. And if they want to stay, they stay on rent-free until the time when they have to give possession. If they want to move out, then they are paid full compensation. They do not have to move out until the date of giving possession is up. And for those in the other phases - there are three phases (first phase is March 1997, second phase is July 1999, third phase is July 2001) - they have ample notice. So taking these factors into consideration - the fact that there is advance notice, the fact that there is a choice and the fact that regardless of when you are leaving, you will be getting a 20% advance compensation very soon - I think the Government, being sympathetic to the plight of affected landowners, has acted to soften the impact.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Sir, in the event the Ministry concerned is not going to pull down the homes after full compensation has been paid and therefore the homes are left vacant, will the Ministry then consider allowing them to stay on at nominal rates? Because the homes are just being left vacant.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: For those staying on after they have been paid full compensation is not the problem. The question is at what rental. The principle is if you are given full compensation at vacant possession rate, in other words, it is a quid pro quo, you are paid that amount to deliver vacant possession, and if you want to stay on, then I think it is fair that you pay market rental as assessed by the Chief Valuer.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Sir, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary will appreciate that this is a very unusual situation where home owners are being asked to move out in view of compulsory acquisition. They are willing to go. It is a question of facilitating

Column: 490

their relocation. So can I ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary what is the problem with allowing them to stay on in a vacant building at nominal rental? It is going to be empty.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Again, as I said, the Government is mindful of the sacrifices that may be made by landowners. In fact, Mr Mah Bow Tan, when he announced in Parliament in January this year, said, and I quote him:

    `The North-East line will bring many benefits to the residents of the North-East. ... But let me stress that there will be sacrifices involved. ... The Government will need to acquire land ... . But these sacrifices are inevitable if we take a long-term perspective and do what is best for the nation. ...' So bearing this in mind, knowing that the project is indeed massive, as I have said earlier on, Government has taken measures in terms of the length of the project, in terms of acquiring these properties in different phases and in terms of even allowing the person to stay on after he has been fully compensated. The Member is right in saying that if the flat or the house is vacant, why not let him stay. And we say, yes, he can stay. He does not even have to physically move out. He can continue staying but, as I said, having been paid full compensation at vacant possession rate, it is fair that he pays market rental.

     Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kampong Glam GRC): Sir, I think the compensation that some Sennett Estate residents got was not full compensation and there was a lot of apprehension as to what was full compensation. And that is why the Member is asking for nominal rental in vacant premises.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Can I have a clarification? Should the owner stay back and not move out, the Senior Parliamentary Secretary has said that he pays market rental. I have the impression that he does not pay the market rental but he pays only for the interest that the Government would have lost by giving full compensation. Is it right?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: No. He wants to remain on the premises after being paid full compensation, ie, the statutory

Column: 491

compensation, which is the value of the property as of 1st January 1995. Beyond that, of course, the ex-gratia payment will take some time to compute. Ex-gratia payment is the difference between the value as of 1st January 1995 and 4th March 1996. Going back to Mr Chiam's point, if the owner wants to remain on the premises after being paid full compensation at vacant possession rate, he pays market rental as assessed by the Chief Valuer. And, Sir, in fact, this is the practice. A property owner who sells his property and wishes to remain on the property after the sale will make an arrangement with his buyer. If he wants to remain on the premises, and the buyer allows him to do it, he will pay market rental, not nominal rental.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Sir, the responses of the Minister for Labour as well as the Minister for Law have been standard answers and they are terms which have already been well publicised and made known to home owners. My point is that in view of the fact that the residents affected by the compulsory acquisition need to facilitate relocation, that they need to reduce the unhappiness and hurt they have suffered all these months in view of the Government's action, that this is a concession on the part of the Ministry concerned. So my question to the Senior Parliamentary Secretary is whether we could allow them to stay on at nominal rates in buildings/flats which would otherwise remain empty and therefore less revenue for Government.

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, Government has made many concessions for this NEL exercise. Earlier on, I have mentioned about the time-frame, the advance notice and also the ex-gratia scheme was amended in June 1996. The ex-gratia scheme is a top-up scheme where besides the statutory compensation as of 1st January 1995, if the property is worth more than what you get for statutory compensation, we value it on 4th March 1996, date of acquisition, and you get the difference subject to a ceiling of $2 million. In addition, this ceiling has been raised from $1.8 million to $2 million. And besides that, previously there was a

Column: 492

condition that if you were an owner-occupier of a residential property and you had another residential property, then you were not entitled to ex-gratia payment. But we have lifted that and as long as you are occupying a residential property, despite the fact that you may have other residential properties, and you are dislocated, you will get ex-gratia payment. And more than that, under the revised scheme in June 1996, owners of acquired shophouses who are doing business in the shophouse will also be entitled to ex-gratia payment.

    So I hope the Member will appreciate this. As I have mentioned earlier, quoting the Minister for Communications, Government is sympathetic to the plight that MPs present on behalf of their constituents. But it is not as though Government has not moved. We have looked at the whole thing in its entirety and, in fact, have packaged in several features that will show that this exercise has been softened for the constituents.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: The Minister says that in relation to shophouses, ex-gratia payments will also be given. Will it be given to the owners of the shophouses or to the tenants?

     Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, compensation money is always paid to the owners because the quid pro quo is that he gives title of the property over to the State.

Column: 492

APPLICATION FOR HDB FLATS
(Relaxation of 30-month debarment period for people affected by compulsory acquisition of land)


    4. Dr Lau Teik Soon asked the Minister for National Development whether he will relax the 30-month debarment period for the application of Housing and Development Board flats for those affected by the compulsory acquisition of land for the North-East MRT line and comprehensive development and, if so, whether he will grant them priority allocation in view of the fact that some of them have to surrender their properties by March 1997.

Column: 493



     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Matthias Yao Chih) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, owners whose private properties are acquired by the State for public development can claim compensation on either encumbered basis or vacant possession basis.

    Owners of private properties which are encumbered would receive lower compensation when their properties are acquired by the State. To help such owners, HDB then exempts them from the 30-month debarment period and the $8,000 income ceiling when they apply for new HDB flats.     The vehicles used for drawing lines on the roads should not spill any paint on the roads while doing the job. This is as the road-marking paint, called thermoplastic paint, comes in powder form. Vehicles that draw road lines have to be fitted with heating devices to turn the powder into liquid form just before the paint is applied on the roads. Paint marks on the roads are likely to be caused by spillage from trucks carrying normal paints, not road-marking paint.
